head.title: Global Warming, Unfortunately, Is All Too Real; Wood Replenishes

hedline.hl1: Global Warming, Unfortunately, Is All Too Real; Wood Replenishes

block.p: Your Sept. 10 front-page article on global warming couples burning of wood with burning of coal and oil as the culprits, a mistake repeated in your Sept. 18 front-page article.
Your Sept. 10 front-page article on global warming couples burning of wood with burning of coal and oil as the culprits, a mistake repeated in your Sept. 18 front-page article.

Burning fossil fuels -- coal, oil and natural gas -- all contribute carbon dioxide to the atmosphere, but wood is constantly being replenished, removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and replenishing our oxygen supply in the process of photosynthesis, thereby offsetting carbon dioxide production and oxygen depletion in the burning process.

But wood growth and burning are not simply a zero sum if we adopt enlightened social policies and economic incentives to increase tree growth. Aside from the global impact on climate, trees afford enormous local benefits of esthetics, shade, of habitat for wildlife, and of wood for use in our country's 25 million fireplaces.

Woodburning with modern technology can provide a supplement of 125,000 megawatts to the country's power supply. That is the power rating of 12 Grand Coulee dams or of all the nuclear power stations in the country. That supplement can enable fossil-fuel-burning utilities with winter power peaks to shave those peaks, and if tree production is encouraged, can reduce carbon buildup in the atmosphere at no cost to utilities but with substantial fuel savings to them and to customers with a cheap source of wood.
And the benefits are of indefinite duration. LAWRENCE CRANBERG Austin, Tex., Sept. 18, 1995 The writer is president of Texas Fireframe Company, which produces grates for fireplaces.
